info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued March 18 at 2:35AM MDT by NWS GrandJunction
info.description: ...SIGNIFICANT MOUNTAIN SNOW EXPECTED EARLY TO MID NEXT WEEK... A series of Pacific storms associated with the next atmospheric river event will impact eastern Utah and western Colorado early to mid next week. Significant snow is expected in all of the mountains with the heaviest amounts projected to fall in the southern and central mountains. At this time, over a foot of snow is possible in the northern ranges with projected accumulations in the 3 to 4 foot range possible for the southern mountains. Mostly rain will fall in the valleys early on in the event but, once colder air moves in towards the midweek point, rain will turn to snow for many valley locations. The northern valleys as well as the southwest Colorado valleys may see several inches of snow with locally higher amounts possible in the foothills of the San Juan Mountains. The main concern in the valleys, particularly early in the week before the colder air arrives, will be the potential for localized flooding due to runoff from impervious areas and/or rain on snow which will enhance runoff rates from snowmelt. In addition to the snow, gusty winds are expected over much of the region as these systems move through, resulting in blowing snow and significantly reduced visibilities at times. Travel, especially over the mountain passes, will be difficult if not impossible at times. Expect winter driving conditions with icy and snow packed roads at higher elevations. There is some uncertainty regarding if there will be any notable break between these two systems, and the exact track of them both. This will ultimately impact final snow totals. Those who are planning to travel across eastern Utah and western Colorado, especially in the mountains, should stay informed of the latest weather forecast at weather.gov/gjt. You can find the latest road conditions for Colorado at cotrip.org, or you can visit udottraffic.utah.gov for conditions in Utah.
